title: Spool Holder (many spool sizes, easy spool exchange)

description.text:
This spool holder can accommodate many different sizes of spools. A pair of cones holds the spool in place and centered. Bearings are used to minimize friction during rotation. Spool exchange is simple: lift the spool/rod from the frame, untighten the wing nut at the two-part cone, take apart the cone, take the rod out of the spool, then do the reverse for the new spool. But don't forget about the wide washer which likes to fall into the spool.
With the default parameters:
  • Spool hole diameters between 29mm and 65mm are supported (limited by the wing nut size and the cone diameter, respectively).
  • Spool widths up to about 100mm are supported. The spool can be wider if its hole is larger, due to the protrusion of the cones.
    This part is designed with my scadgen Python tool, which can output OpenSCAD or OpenJSCAD code. To generate OpenSCAD and open the result:
    python2.7 /main.py filament_holder.py -o out.scad -s
    • Updates:
  • Made certain holes octagonal for easier printing.

Bill of materials:
  • All the printed parts (part counts are in the file names).
  • 40x M8 washers.
  • 36x M8 nuts.
  • 2x wide M8 washer for the cones (optional, regular washers can be used instead). Note that too wide washers may not fit into the spool.
  • 1x M8 wing nut.
  • 2x 608 bearing.
  • 2x ~38mm M4 threaded rods to hold the cone together (can be cut from a screw).
  • M8 threaded rods for the frame: 2x 215mm (bottom triangle edges), 4x 145mm (upper triangle edges), 3x 190mm (horizontal rods connecting the triangles).
    Assemble as shown on the pictures. Some things are worth mentioning:
  • Glue the bearing covers to the top vertices. This is needed because the geometry is difficult to print.
  • The two-part cone is actually made of two different pieces, where one has slightly narrower holes. The two supporting M4 threaded rods are screwed into this part and stay in place.
  • The assembly at the fixed cone is not visible on the pictures. Starting form the end of the rod, it consists of: nut, washer, bearing, washer, washer, washer, wide washer, cone, washer, nut.

title: Rostock with fishing braid drive lines

description.text:
This is my variation on the Rostock printer. It is pretty much Johann's original design with the following changes: 1) Braid fishing line instead of belts for main axis drives,
2) Threaded drive pulleys to prevent braid tangles,
3) Use of planetary gear box on extruder,
4) Custom Bowden hot-end holder. The main reason for the braid in place of the drive belts was that I was finding it hard to source GT2 timing belts/pulleys, and braid fishing line was a cheap alternate that a friend suggested I try. I was a bit skeptical that the braid would work, but so far it has proven to be most effective.

The braid line I used was "Spectra Extreme Braid" 0.48mm, with approximately 2.5m needed for each of the 3 axes. I simply tied loops in the ends and used cable ties to tension the lines. To drive the braid I designed and printed a custom drive pulley and a v-groove pulley for the top end idler. 3 of each of these is required. I did not add any support when slicing the pulleys, as the maximum overhang (other than screw holes) is 45 degrees, and the in-fill was 0.3. For an extruder driver I printed Airtripper's bowden extruder v3 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:35404). At the time I was fascinated with gearboxes (with visible gears) so I decided to print Ellindsey's Extruder motor planetary gearbox (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:39558) to gear the extruder down. Since the gearbox is quite large I ended up mounting it through a cut out in the plywood frame. For the hot-end end of the bowden unit I designed and printed a custom holder that marries nicely to the rostock platform. It is designed to hold a 1.75mm filament Makergear hot-end and clamps the PTFE tube using a 4mm nut. In I have included support in the design of the top half of the holder, meaning no support is required when slicing the stl. The hot-end holder was printed in ABS, and seems to standing up to the heat generated for ABS printing. All other plastic parts were printed in PLA, with a layer thickness of 0.25mm. Things to improve:
  • The braid drive pulley was printed with 24 facets per revolution. This needs to be redone with with more facets as there is a noticeable flick on the braid as the pulley rotates.
  • Also a smaller diameter might be better as is will improve resolution (more motor steps per mm). Currently my steps per mm is around 35, which is just over 2 real motor steps when the micro-stepping (16) is taken into account. I am not sure how micro-stepping really affects things...
  • Add some filament guides.

comments.text: I also build Rostock with fishing line, but now switch to GT2 belts. Line is not so "rigid" and not able for very fast movements. And also lines give you different steps per mm for different towers. It is bad if you use repetier firmware (it require same steps on all towers), so in marlin it works ok, but there is no working autobedleveling in marlin. So now I use GT2 belts with repetier firmware and like my printer works. Lines not so good as belts :)
comments.author: kindrat

comments.text: Your going about the tie in off part wrong, one end gets tied it the upper part your moving piece, then it gets wrapped around your pulley and down to your drive pulley where you wrap it around 4 times and the back up to the lower side where you will then set the tension, the the point of this is to use lateral friction instead of teeth if your wrapping it more than a few times around you're actually changing the length and losing tension the point isn't to throw it around as much as you're moving but to use it as a belt......that would be why this one doesnt have a tie off hole ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:70377 ), sorry not trying to pick on you about it, it is a good design but because of the size you will lose torque and because of how your winding it your going to make he distance of travel grow the further it travels, but good job on the design, it is a nice piece , I did print one and played with it a bit
comments.author: jlipavsky79

comments.text: Thanks for the comments.  It has been a fair while since I have looked at using braid line - have moved on to more traditional GT2 belts and pulleys.  I agree with your comment about the diameter of the pulleys and the torque and and precision lost when using the ones I did.

I simply loop and tie it off around one of the spokes, then thread it through the hole on the edge and wind around the grooves.  I do the same through the other side as well, so that rotating the pulley will wind on side on and the other side off.

author: rlittin

description.text:
I have the Suncast slat wall system in my garage and need to hang some tools that have some weight. Let's face it, we all know when you 3D print pegs they are only so strong even with high infills. So, I decided to use a metal bolt at an angle that would fit into a 3D printing that snaps into the slat system. It is designed for the Suncast slat wall sections which are sold by Home Depot and other home improvement centers.
https://www.suncast.com/sw04.html
https://www.suncast.com/sheds-storage/garage-storage/slat-wall-systems.html

Settings (Suggested)
Raft: On
Supports: On
Infill: 35% Suggested to make sure 'pegs' are strong.
Shells: 3
Layer Height: 0.20mm
After printing,clean up and remove raft and supports with an xacto knife. Be careful not to damage pegs during cleaning. File as necessary for good fit in slat board. Ream the hole with a 6mm drill for the bolt. The hole is at 10° angle. I used a 6mm x 40mm bolt with a 10mm hex head. Insert bolt from backside. The hex head should fit snugly. Use a 6mm nut to tighten on the front side.This is very strong and can hold some very heavy tools.

description.text:
Its holder for engine type 6364C.
The scooter micro (swiss made), both wheels are remade, in front costs 175mm, behind 152mm (6 inches wide). On the motor costs freewheel 13T or 16T. Behind from 16T to 22T. Depends on necessary power. If to put 16T, for a set of speed it is necessary to make a start well, but thus you save a battery charge. Uphill over 6% won't pull. This holder of the motor is intended for acquaintance and further understanding of its improvement. Heating of external walls of the motor is in use found. But the kilometer will pass without consequences))
If you wish to create the scooter, please use controlers from 150A and above. 100A it isn't enough, they burn down. Any questions, set in comments, I will answer that other participants also got experience.

author: OliverWS

description.text:
This is a customizable rose pattern also known as a rhodonea curve.
See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rose_%28mathematics%29

WARNING: It seems that the STL cannot be generated for some reason. I have rewritten this into a working script. Please use this instead : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:50249 This script will generate an artistic rendering of a Rhodonea curve (Rose). You can set the N and D values to affect the look of the curve (see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Rose-rhodonea-curve-7x9-chart-improved.svg).
You can either use a sphere, a cube or a cylinder to draw the points of the curve (I prefer sphere), and define how many points you want to be used to draw the result. You can also control the size of the pencil and the thickness of the curve. The rose radius will set the radius of the petals. This will basically mean that the rose should fit in a circle with that radius. It is highly suggested not to enable the "high detail" option as it will take a very long time to generate the preview. I would suggest to use 100 points if you enable it. It does give better results, if you are ready to wait for it to finish rendering. The 3D effect allows you to control how the shape will look in 3D space. None means it will be a flat surface showing the rose, the sinus, cosinus and sinus+cosinus will use different algorithms to move the rose through 3D space into a weird shape. The rose will still be visible the same way if looked at directly from the top. The "rose" 3d effect will use the same algorithm to generate the rose as to determine the position of the point on the Z axis. This has the effect of generating a sort of looping of the petals of the rose.
Experiment and enjoy!

description.text: This is the laser cutter I've spent alot of time on a few months ago, It uses a gantry crane design to cheaply and effectively make a laser cutter that is very accurate. It requires 2x nema 17 motors, 1/4-20 threaded rod, 1/8in smooth rod, 1/8 bearings, 1/4-20 threaded nut, laser assembly, a 3d printer (duh), and some ingenuity. At 13y/o I can design virtually anything in solidworks, and 3d print it with my da vinci, but i'm not great at grbl programming. That's where I could use some help setting this up so I can further this project and get some fully working prototypes, as the only way of testing lately is with some arduino script running easy drivers in basic patterns. This design has worked very well so far with some aluminum sheet as a base to screw the assembly onto, software is the major roadblock.

• Print out x axis and mirrored x axis and place them so that the tabs/legs face out.
  • Print out crane arm and mirrored crane arm and place them so that the smooth plates are touching.
  • Use 2 Smooth rod bearings and drill up as necessary to fit them in the gantry/crane arm holes furthest from the center, repeat for both sides.
  • Thread two 1/8in smooth rods through the holes furthest from center in the x axis piece and have them go through the gantry arm bearings locking the gantry arms into the system.
    5.glue a 1/4-20 nut between the two crane arms connecting them together forming one axis, then use one nema 17 motor+coupler and thread the 1/4-20 rod through the x axis piece through the gantry arm nut all the way to the other piece (mirrored x axis).
    6.Drill up and use one 1/8in bearing on the laser assembly, Then glue one 1/4-20 nut into the larger hole of the assembly.
  • Mount the nema 17 motor onto the motor mount in the gantry arm and thread one 1/4-20 threaded rod and coupler through the laser assembly until it reaches the mirrored gantry arm, use 1/8in smooth rod through the gantry arm pieces proceeding through the laser assembly.
  • Print bed holder and (once I upload the part) print out mirrored bed holder and glue it in place using the hexagonal pegs built into the x axis, repeat for both sides.
  • Use aluminum sheet and create a bed for the cut item to lay on, glue on bed holders.
  • Use aluminum sheet or other material and create a sturdy surface to mount assembly onto.
  • Use arduino and easy drivers to wire assembly and potential end stops (help needed programming).
  • laser cut a coaster and use accordingly.

This is my 2nd version of a bed stabilizer. the tiny hole in the middle is for a small nail that locks spring in place. Bearing holders came from Adonirams design I found on Thingiverse you need 2 of them . You will also need 2 5mm x 11mm 2 mm bearings. ( I got from BocaBearing.com).

print 2 bearing holders   1 Y stabilizer cut 2  pieces of .175 ( 3/16 inch) thick steel rods (got at local hobby shop) approximately 5.25 inches long. Then cut a compression spring (from local hardware store) approximately 1.75 inches long . Set spring in middle of Y stabilizer and push small nail thru hole . add bearings to each side and install in center of bed bottom rail . I ground end of steel rods for a tight fit.

description.text: As the title says, its an APM/PX4/Pixhawk pitot tube cover. I designed this for two reasons; 1) Easy calibration 2) Protection during transport. It  covers 55mm of pitot tube, which seems to be enough for most pitot tubes protruding from a wing or nose. This probably wont work well when externally mounted with a bracket, as it is designed for the first 1cm or so to be encased in an airframe, glue, etc. I almost made a flange for it so it would butt up perfect against my airframe, but then realized it will only work on my airframe (which is not on the market... yet) so I designed it for everyone. As a warning, if your printer is not tuned well and cannot make a perfect circle, this may fit a bit tighter than it should. With an accurate printer it will fit snug, but not too snug or it will be air tight and wont allow you to calibrate. If it fits a bit loose, I fixed it with a single layer of Scott magic tape (no more than exactly ONE layer!) This should be placed at the base, not the tip, and the pitot tube will slide on and be secured with a bit of friction. perfect for transport.

Just print at as fine resolution as you are willing (.1mm-.3mm). It should slide right over the pitot tube. If it is a tad loose, use a single layer of scotch (clear) tape at the base (NOT THE TIP!). This will help secure it during aircraft transportation. I have found that this is not air tight, enough to disrupt pitot/static calibration, however with the tape in place it often can become air tight, or close enough to mess with calibration. This being said, if you use the tape method to secure it for transport, simply slide it past the tape so that it is no longer air tight (snug is fine), then calibrate your apm/pixhawk. You might experience a slight change in airspeed and altitude as you slide it off, however once removed completely airspeed and altitude should return to zero. Goodluck!

description.text:
Reciever mount for the spidex pro.
Matches frsky l9r reciever but probobly fit alot more.
Mounts on the back inbetween the batterytray and the main frame
This prototype is the first step to making a fully functional 3D-printed glasses. The frame is made with FDM and lenses with SLS. It is even possible to custom design your own package!

The lenses are made to be a snug fit in the frame. To secure use a little bit of plastics glue. Polishing
To finish the printed lenses to the right optical quality I advice to use waterproof sanding paper (grain 800). (Sanding should be done by using water!)
After sanding, you should polish the surface of the part with Unipol, which you can get from any DIY-shop. I discovered that the manner of polishing the lens is important for the blurriness of the photo's. I consider to be real precise on the quality of every step. Don't rush it will finally take longer. See link below. Bleaching
I also tried to bleach the whole lens using a fluorescent lamp. It is hard to keep your object just 40 degrees Celsius. It is important to keep it close to 40Â°C. If it gets to 45Â°C your lens will turn a bit yellow and less clear. See link below. Polishing: http://objet.com/sites/default/files/pdfs/Polishing.pdf
Bleaching: http://objet.com/sites/default/files/pdfs/DOC-08299_A_Photobleaching-Objet-VeroClear+.pdf

title: FPV Tricopter 1.3GHz 300mW Transmitter Mount (1/2 Inch and 10MM Booms)

description.text:
This is a vertical mount for my tricopters 1.3ghz transmitter used for FPV flight.
Please post up the ones that you make. Let me know if you like the mount. (*UPDATE 10mm Booms. Make sure you download correct size.)
10mm Carbon boom mount added, would recommend putting some sticky tape in the back to prevent sliding. Have you broken one of these yet in a wreck? I have broken two tail booms with this mount on there and haven't seen any stress marks in the plastic, just bent antennas. Post up some pics of the ones you've made.

The transmitter used is ReadyMadeRC's 1.3GHz 300mW transmitter. The mount is designed for 1/2 inch booms. Print flat on the back. I printed with support using 30% fill. The mount weighes 8 grams at that infill. You will need 3 small zipties and a file. Clean off all the support material and grab your file. Use the file on the inside of the pocket until your transmitter can slide in snugly. DO NOT use the lower ear to push the transmitter in, it isn't a support piece without the boom in the lower slot. Once the transmitter is in use one ziptie in the slot on the top. That will keep the transmitter from sliding out. Next, two more zipties in the lower slots inserted from the front side. Slide onto 1/2 boom. Tighten zipties.
Transmitter: http://www.readymaderc.com/store/index.php?main_page=product_info&cPath=11_30_38&products_id=1017

description.text: Skeinforge wasn\\'t happy with the last version of the Hexagonal Box, and after some discussion on the Thingiverse Google Group (recommended reading, by the way), Zach pointed out that non-manifold vertices were a possible culprit. Well, turns out he was right! I went back to Sketchup, eliminated all the points in the model where two pieces of the model touched along a single edge, ran it thru MeshLab to check for mesh defects and export to STL, scaled the STL in Blender, and then ran SkeinForge on the STL file... getting a beautiful toolpath. Thanks to everyone on the Group for the suggestions/tips/tricks! http://groups.google.com/group/thingiverse

With Skeinforge happy with the STL file, and the toolpath visualization showing decent detail on the lock tabs, the only thing left is to print one out for final validation!
According to Skeinforge, it should take a little less than 17,000 seconds and 31cc of material to make this Thing. Call it 4 hours and 45 minutes. :-D
As with previous versions, six of these should lock together to make a box, and it\\'s recommended to assemble two (three section) halves and mate those last.

description.text:
This Thing has an ID number of 5000. 
This Thing consists of an image of its own QR Code, a Sketchup file containing the designs for its own QR Code, and an STL file which, when printed, will result in its own QR code being printed.  
All files uploaded have the same file name, but different extensions.
It is one of the few (only?) Things on Thingiverse which is functionally equivalent whether you print out the image using a 2D printer or the physical object described by the STL using a 3D printer.
EXACTLY 5000 characters total were used in the names of all files, the name, description, and Instructions. (The previous sentence was a blatant lie).

1) Print.
2) Scan the QR Code.
3) Go to Thing brought up by the QR Code.
4) Follow instructions for Thing brought up by the QR Code.

title: Printrbot Simple Metal Filament Cradle V2.0

description.text:
Updated to hike up the shafts going down to allow full Z travel, and shortened the "wheel base" to allow it to hold smaller spools, such as nylon.  Also prints as a single piece (not including the wheels)).  Also made it able to hold narrower spools.  
Thing to hold a variety of filament spools on top of a Printrbot Simple Metal.  Designed to hold the spool clear of the full travel of the Z axis, with a minimal mechanism.  The spool might spin OK w/o the bearings, but, hey, why not ?
Uses 4 planetary bearing (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:497136).
Built and in use on my machine.

Print with ABS or similar strong and stiff material, 100% fill, so that wider spools of filament will not bow the spreaders. Flip the part on its back, shaft mounts facing up. Print four of the planetary bearings (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:497136), to slide over the spreaders .

Note: updates have been made to this design and are available through the links on the instructions tab (I don't want to maintain two locations). For example: there are now 4 Z axis options available to accommodate your build size and preferences.
-original (2 rear leadscrews), shown modeled in red
-original offset, in OpenBuilds rework and D-bot remix, shown modeled in purple
-Front back, in OpenBuilds rework and used by AK-EriC, shown modeled in green
-3 lead screw options, developed by AdamCooks on OpenBuilds Parts & BOM:
http://www.openbuilds.com/builds/c-bot.1146/
Discussion:
https://plus.google.com/u/0/communities/106707229610255461517
Build Blog:
http://www.akeric.com/blog/?page_id=2
Build Guide:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1001065
Modifications & Accessories:
http://www.thingiverse.com/cfeniak/collections/c-bot

This is a Core XY printer that makes use of open builds V-Slot rails.
I designed this myself with a couple goals in mind:
-not to use any linear rod/bearings; I used V-slot for all guided motion
-no crossing belts as found in most core XY printers; I used two offset parallel belt runs
-run the belts through the extrusion when possible for a cleaner end product
-make the entire setup easily modifiable and adaptable so others can use it for alternate bed sizes
(I am using an 8x12, but changing to an 8x8, 10x10, or 12"x12" is as easy as cutting your extrusion to different lengths, no part redesign required)
-a lesser goal was to minimize the amount of unique 3D printed parts required, but since I already have a functioning home built OB1.4, this goal fell by the wayside. None the less, you can see printed parts like corners and tees that can be replaced with items from the open builds parts store.

comments.text:
Hello,
Sorry for asking so many questions lately....
So if I want to make the version with triple lead screws for the Z-axis, is there any physical changes for the frame, or is it just a matter of printing some different parts? Also I want to drive all three lead screws with a single motor driven by a belt. I plan to use a NEMA-23 here so is there any modifications that I need to make here?
Thanks,
Taylor
comments.author: BinaryNightowl

comments.text: Mostly the same parts.  You need to add a cross member to the front of heated bed platform and perhaps one at the bottom of the frame as well to hold the drive motor.  Otherwise you use the same parts and remixed prints for the 3 leadscrew setup.  I haven't seen nema 23 version though.  Would be easy to design a motor bracket for it though.

comments.text:
Hello,
I am thinking about making a very large version of this printer. I am thinking about 550x550x650mm build volume. Because this is almost twice as large as the 12x12in that you stated in the description, would this work at this size? What changes do I need to make? Will it work with E3D Chimera bowden? And finally would you recommend this or the D-Bot?
Thanks,
Taylor Dettling
comments.author: BinaryNightowl

comments.text: That is pretty substantial in size. Your challenges will be frame rigidity, squaring, and the Z axis. Use Aluminum plates where you can instead of the standard plastic printed ones. Use one of the many three leadscrew Z axis mods for the Z axis (see http://www.thingiverse.com/cfeniak/collections/c-bot). Keep the moving bar light (bowden). There is a remix Chimera carriage on Thingiverse, but I can't imagine not using a single or dual volcano hotend for this build volume.
comments.author: BinaryNightowl

comments.text: When you say triple Z, should I do three lead screws driven by one motor with belts or three independent z-motors? I can see the Z axis getting out of sync but with a MIC-6 aluminum plate that’s ~16-18 in squared, I doubt a single Nema 17 could do that alone. I calculate it needs to lift 18.5 pounds of aluminum + weight of print........
comments.author: cfeniak

comments.text: You can still probably do it with a single large/long nema 17 if you use a low pitch lead screw (2mm pitch versus the 8mm I use) and pulley reduction.  A 20 or even 16 tooth drive pulley and 36 or 40 tooth driven pulley on the 3 lead screws.
comments.author: BinaryNightowl

comments.text:
Have you checked out the open builds site? There are some extra photos in the discussion too.
It is a coreXY setup just like: http://www.corexy.com/theory.html
However, the belts "cross over" in the reference mechanism I linked to at the top/back. That ends up looking like this: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:22005 The cross over is required here as the belts run in the same XY plane.
I wanted to avoid the cross over so I offset the two belt runs by 20mm. This also enabled me run the belts partially through the extrusion. You can see this by looking at the hotend carriage and looking where the belts attach on the left versus right side.

comments.text:
I like that the V-Slot is dual purpose and can be used both structurally and as a guide for linear motion. Reduces cost and can simplify a build.
A perfect 90 cut would be great... but isn't going to happen in typical home setups. Fortunately the brackets can accommodate these imperfections as the exterior clamping on the uncut surfaces defines their alignment and not the cut end surface. Small differences in length can be adjusted for by slightly moving the extrusion in and out of the bracket to easily square off the frame. That is an advantage of the V slot compared to a defined hole location for positioning.
comments.author: DarkAlchemist

description.text:
This Thing has an ID number of 5001.
It is only really useful for propagating derivative copies of it's parent Thing, the Thing with an ID number of 5000.
If you print it successfully, you will have a stamp capable of creating QR codes for it's parent Thing.
I seriously considered swapping out all files, imagines, and descriptions between Thing #5001 and Thing #5000 so that Thing #5000 could be it's own derivative.
For heaven's sake, whatever you do, do NOT make a derivative of this Thing!!!

remixed_from.author: CodeCreations
remixed_from.title: Modified Endplate for Fully Printable Eggbot

description.text:
I started with the revised fully printable eggbot here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:20398
and found the servos on hand didn't fit well and had to work too hard.
There was also some backlash in the original pen design that I could only fix by crushing the pen so the pen holder has had some adjustments made.

Make an eggbot attach these parts in place of the originals.
I have to rotate them in before slicing and the servo does need support.

My purpose was to remove as much backlash as I could and make a more accurate eggbot.
This is an "upgrade" to Glasswalkers eggbot pen arm.
A better term might be this is a specialization of the original.
The shaft mount is not included but I am still using the original.
The pen securing bolts and nuts are sized for m3x8 and are sized tight enough that a nut may not be needed.
The slider bolt slot is also m3.
The pen aperture will not fit a normal sharpie, but will fit the art type ink pens or a sharpie fine.
The servo mount is for a 9g hobby servo I got for 3$ at the rc store

remixed_from.author: alexmac
remixed_from.title: Super Mario Power Star stl model

title: Super Mario Power Star (remeshed & dual + single extrusion)

description.text:
I wanted a Super Mario Power Star to complement my Dual Extrusion 1UP Mushroom and Mystery Box. The existing version contains some very stretched polygons, so I remeshed the body.
I created both a single and dual extrusion version. I used the latter as a test print for my Big Builder Dual Review on http://nicklievendag.com

Printed on the Big Builder Dual feed at 100 micron. The disc is to ensure the second color is purged. I used Cura's Wipe & Prime Tower, but because it doesn't retract when going from or to that, I still got some black where it doesn't belong. I printed it without support.

I found my old skateboard in the attic and i had over 10 years fun with skateboarding.
Of course it deserves a better place where i can see it.
So I created a hook for the trucks.
If someone has the same idea, here is already the hook ;-).
Maybe he does not fit for every board, but you can scale it a little.
At 100% size must the distance between weel weel
minimum 109 mm (4.3 ").
Active skater are welcome to test whether it fits on newer trucks,
my last board is from 2002 :-) I added also a small version,but i recommend a strong wall for it.

• I printed with 20% infill and it is very stable, maybe go even with less.
  • There is no support needed

author: kapoll

description.text: Chaise Longue

Final update: I have uploaded the source scad and DXF files, and an archive with all the STLs, including the improved ones by nicholasclewis (thank you!). I lost some of the source files for the first models by accident, and the bunny idler was not made in OpenSCAD, and I don't have the source for models made by others, but most of them are there. Have fun building, and don't forget the contest! Starting today, December 2nd, I will upload a new STL each day. Print one per day and you'll have a Prusa Mendel (with extruder) on the 24th. The prints that take longer are on the weekends, with shorter ones during the week. Some of the parts are special holiday-themed. I'll try to arrange them so you can build as much as possible with the ones you already have. All of these will fit on a normal Makerbot build platform. For more information on the Prusa Mendel, see http://www.reprap.org/wiki/Prusa_Mendel For the source code for the models, see https://github.com/prusajr/PrusaMendel Superlative update! Ruben (sikko on IRC) of ikmaak.nl is organizing a contest for everyone who is printing this. The best resulting printer gets a free set of electronics, and the runner-up gets free filament. So if you are printing this, check http://ikmaak.nl/eenblog/2010/12/06/the-holiday-mendel-build-contest/ for the contest details. The STL for 02. December is now available.
It's a Wade extruder idler by nophead, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3462 The STL for 03. December is now available.
It's three of the universal rod clamps that you need for the Y and Z axes.
The snowflakes are from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1321
You can hang them from your frame top bars if you like.
This is the Prusa Mendel bar-clamp part. The STL for 04. December is now available.
If you can have a vertex with a foot...
then why not have a vertex...with a boot!
This part is equivalent to frame-vertex-foot in the Prusa Mendel The STL for 05. December is now available.
The irregularly shaped hole on the y motor bracket just got more regular.
This is equivalent to the y-motor-bracket The STL for 06. December is now available.
Courtesy of GregFrost, we have a decorated vertex that proudly proclaims the name of the remix's designer. Print as it is, and don't worry about the missing bits on the first layer - they're there on purpose.
This is equivalent to the frame-vertex. The STL for 07. December is now available.
For all of you who were waiting for the other shoe to drop - here it is.
Should print better than the one before - less of the boot is hanging in the air.
This is equivalent to frame-vertex-foot. The STL for 08. December is now available.
This is a tree-star vertex. While the front of your bot has boots, why not have something nice for the back too?
This is equivalent to frame-vertex-foot. Once you've printed this part you are ready to assemble one of the frame triangles. Take this part and the one from the day before it, and the crown vertex, and follow the instructions on the wiki page linked above. The STL for 09. December is now available.
We've already got bar-clamps, why not star-clamps?
Sadly the thumbnail does not show the most interesting bit.
This is the Prusa Mendel bar-clamp part. The STL for 10. December is now available.
Another lovely vertex by GregFrost. Print as it is, and don't worry about the missing bits on the first layer - they're there on purpose and spell out the model name.
This is equivalent to the frame-vertex. The STL for 11. December is now available.
Another tree-star vertex.
This is equivalent to frame-vertex-foot. You can now build the entire frame! Have fun! The STL for 12. December is now available.
It's a gift and motor holder. It holds your z motor and a bunch of gifts - and anything else you put on it. Using clothbot's parametric LEGO buttons at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1005 makes this part LEGO-compatible.
This is equivalent to z-motor-holder. The STL for 13. December is now available.
Since the LEGO bits from yesterday turned out so popular, here's more of that.
Four belt clamps, two rod clamps, two bar clamps. Enjoy!
(There was an error in this file. If you downloaded it before this message appeared, please download it again. If you already printed it, you will need to reprint it. Sorry! My mistake!) The STL for 14. December is now available.
These are the prusa bushings. They work best if printed in PLA, so if you have access to PLA, use that for this part.
These are the bushings for all three axes. The STL for 15. December is now available.
These are pulleys for the X and Y axes. Use the shooting star pulley on the X axis, and the other on the Y. You can now build the entire Y axis. The STL for 16. December is now available.
This is a quiet little street behind a purring Z axis motor.
This is equivalent to z-motor-holder. The STL for 17. December is now available.
Two little trees to hold your leadscrews in line.
This is equivalent to coupling. The STL for 18. December is now available.
tbuser's lovely scanned gnome http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4693 finds its way back to the real world, guarding your x axis motor.
This is equivalent to x-end-motor. The STL for 19. December is now available.
I was so impressed when the Stanford bunny appeared on thingiverse as http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3731 and immediately printed 4.
This one will sit on your idler and watch your prints for you.
This is equivalent to x-end-idler. Now you have all the parts you need to build the X axis and attach it to the Z axis. The STL for 20. December is now available.
It's an x-carriage...with a beard. More on this theme later. You can now attach the bushings and belt for the X axis. The STL for 21. December is now available.
This is the small gear for a Wade's extruder - with a candy cane on top. The STL for 22. December is now available.
This is the body of Wade's extruder, only with a hat!
(could you, would you, with a hat?) The STL for 23. December is now available.
This is the large gear for the the Wade's extruder. It's meant to look pretty cool with the other extruder parts and the bearded carriage.
Moustache profile from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4626 You can now assemble the entire extruder. The STL for 24. December is now available.
These are the endstop holder sleighs.
Racing through the bed.
On a one-stop open axis.
Who will reach it first...
At G28. You can now assemble the entire printer. Tomorrow, you get OpenSCAD source and a zip of all the models.

title: New York Rangers Engraving
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: For my first project I laser engraved a wooden plaque. The design is Henrik Lundqvist's 2011-2012 goalie mask.

To create this engraving I used a photo of Henrik's mask and, in Photoshop, removed the background. Then I transferred the photo to Illustrator and added the text "Henrik Lundqvist #30 New York Rangers".  Lastly, I sent the file to the CNC Epilog Laser with DPI 300, speed 100, and power 75. If I were to redo this project, I would change the text to a bolder font because it was very light/thin.

author: snkovacs

title: Centrifugal Fan Mount for Simple Metal

description.text: This is a simple, direct approach for mounting a centrifugal blower type fan on to a Printrbot Simple Metal (model 1403). The mount clips directly onto the frame that is sandwiched between the stepper motor that feeds the filament and the hot end that is mounted below. Secure your blower fan in place with a screw and nut, make your electrical connections, and enjoy!

Designed directly in Sketchup Make. The SKP file is included so you can easily make your own modifications.
Just be sure that the longer side of the mount's orientation is on the bottom for a secure fit. Have your Z axis homed when you secure the fan in place, that way you can guarantee the fan won't scrape your printer's bed at the angle you've chosen. Work In Progress
After doing a couple long prints (10 hr+) the mount does not fit as snugly as it first did. So I've designated this thing as a work in progress while I make some revisions (or someone else beats me to it).

This is an adaptor for mounting a sticky lint-roller refill on the end of a Swiffer handle so my wife can get the cat hair off the top of her convertible.
The locking buttons are slightly out of place in the photos, but have been corrected in the SCAD and STL files.

Print without support. There should be enough clearance around the locking tabs and their springs that they break loose easily.  
Squeeze the ends of the horizontal pieces inward and upward to mount the lint roll or to remove it.  It spins most freely when held with the vertical piece downwards.

I needed some knobs for rotary encoders and rotary switches for a project I am working on ( fsx flight panels ).
.
They were printed at 100 micron setting on my Replicator 2, there is a channel a nut can be slid into, and then the screw clamps against the switch shaft.
.
The small rotary selector switch needs an M2.5 nut and bolt, and I had to hacksaw the bolt to shorten it.
.
The larger encoder knob needs am M3 x 12 mm bolt, and will fit without modification.
.
I have included the Fusion360 files.

remixed_from.title: Y Endstop Holder For Back Rod For Prusa Mendel

title: Z and Y endstops for 8mm +M8 rods

description.text:
My Z endstop worked well once I calibrated the machine -BUT- every time you slightly hit the endstop the Z calibration was gone du to a jiggling holder. So: I designed this one with some additional mm of guidance on the 8mm rod. Diameters:
3.5mm (2x M3 screws for clamping)
2.5mm (2x M2 screw for endstop; 10mm dist.) ...you can also glue your endstop to your holder if you don't get M2 screws.

If you do not have something to print at the same bunch print at least 2 of them due to the heat of your printed filament and the thin wall width. (Of course you only need one....) To remove all knobs caused by printing use a 8mm drill to remove them! Thanks by the way to rrhb for the y endstop!
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15683

This is a simple Y axis tensioner i made for the k8200. I made this to tighten my GT2 belt. The belt was rubbing on the x axis rail, so this tensioner lowers the belt out of contact. Parts needed are:
  • 1 x 625 5 x 16 x 5mm bearing
  • 1 x 5mm bolt (at least 20mm long)
  • 2 x 5mm washers
  • 1 x 5mm nut
  • 2 x 3mm bolts (at least 15mm long)
  • 2 x 3mm nuts

UPDATE 2/13/17
Revision 2 that I worked on way back when but never had the need to make again. Remade them this time in stainless steel on a water jet cutting machine, but the vector and source files uploaded are the slotted and tabbed versions intended for a CNC router or laser cutter. Enjoy! Portal inspired book ends! Cut out on a shapeoko 2, but a laser cutter would work well too.

1) Use the vector file to create your paths
2) Separate each part out to cut/laser on the correct colors
3) Cut/laser out each part
4) Glue and assemble I used a shapeoko 2 to cut it out. My settings were 15 IPM feed, .02" step down per pass and "high medium" for spindle speed. (my speed controller does not have any numbers on it). I used a 1/16" square end mill and all the corner reliefs are designed to take that into account.

description.text:
Create your own set of vases that come together to form the shape of a flower! 
You can create from three to eight petals, select how tall you want the vases, and what style of neck each petal has.

Customize as you desire, save the STL, and print!
You should print these with at least one extra shell, though two or three is better, and at a high infill for weight (100% infill will also ensure water-tightness).
The inside of each petal vase is angled to not create overhangs, so there's no need for rafts or supports when printing.
NOTE 1: there is a rendering issue with the "fluted" neck style. The exported STL will be fine, it will just look weird in Customizer.
NOTE 2: the overall width of the vases, and the max height, is made to fit on the build plate of a Thing-o-Matic but you can scale up once you have the STL, if you so desire.

title: Waterline 1/4" adapter nut for Nylon drybox

description.text: Hey, it is a nut!  I wanted to use this 1/4" waterline adapter for the filament feed-through on a drybox I am making for printing with Nylon.  I hadn't been able to find a standard nut for these 1/4" waterline adapters so I made one.  I measured the threads using the 3 wire method.  For those that care, I measured 18 Threads per inch and a pitch diameter of 0.481".  I made my pitch diameter 0.492".  Major diameter is 0.529".  It fits perfectly.  IGS file included if you want to tweak it.

author: taitrt

title: Dizzy the 5DOF Biped Robot
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I was inspired a long time ago by the BOB Biped robot by k1201289 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:43708 and have made a few since. I wanted to give something back to the new makers out there, like I had the chance to get Bob so long ago now. I didn't want to go overboard, so the addition of 1 extra servo isn't all that much on an original bob build, so if you have an old one laying around, this could be a new home for those parts!
The main difference with this Biped is the inclusion of the 5th servo, which allows the head to rotate (360' if you have the correct servo) and detect obstacles. The thighs are also angled at 15 degrees to give the bot more stability when walking.

remixed_from.author: odino
remixed_from.title: Another new and Alternative x-end for prusa i3

title: minimal Prusa i3 x ends: zip ties, built-in adjustable tensioner and easy z height adjustor

description.text:
Prusa i3 x ends for zip ties with built in adjustable tensioner. Designed for maximum functionality with minimal filament use.
I took odino's version and added in the built-in adjustable idler and separators for the LM8UUs.
EDIT: Oct 20, 2014: added in built in z height adjustor (that I had put on a previous version of the x motor piece that I've been using in my i3 kit) - see x-end_zippy_SemiU_zadj.stl
Download github repository to get scad file with all its dependencies: https://github.com/gcolbourn/Prusa3-SemiU

Use M4x25 bolt, M4 nut, 4 M4 washers and 2 624ZZ bearings for idler.
The cable ties can be a bit fiddly to thread through. If anyone knows an easy technique for this, please comment.
Thread M3x25 bolt through z adjustor hole for a tight friction fit, and position z endstop underneath. Can then precisely adjust z home position by turning bolt with alan key (1 turn is usually 0.5mm).

comments.text: Is this model mean't to be mounted with the x rods being on the other side of the z rods as to standard x ends. Normally, the x smooth rods go between the z smooth rods and the prusa frame but on this model they seem to be mounted on the other side of the z rods. Does this impact stability in any way, especially with a wooden frame?
comments.author: Streuli273

comments.text: Hi, I guess we've always had the rods round that way - thinking about it, it probably would improve stability a bit having them the other way, but we get pretty good print quality as it is. Will probably reverse them round at some point though, thanks for the heads up.
